importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the lawsuit filing and key developments in the political standoff between Arizona and the U.S. House of Representatives.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from late September 2025 to October 21, 2025, when Adelita Grijalva won her election and faced a delay in swearing-in, highlighting the timeline of political conflict and legal action.

keyTakeAways: Arizona’s attorney general has sued the U.S. House of Representatives over Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to swear in newly elected Democrat congresswoman Adelita Grijalva.
The lawsuit claims that the Constitution requires elected members to be sworn in upon election, and that the Speaker has no constitutional authority to delay the swearing-in process.
Speaker Mike Johnson cited a precedent set by Nancy Pelosi during past recesses, stating he would administer the oath only upon the House’s return to regular session.
The lawsuit alleges that Johnson’s delay is politically motivated, aiming to stifle a petition on Jeffrey Epstein records and strengthen his position in budget negotiations.
Arizona argues that the refusal to seat Grijalva undermines democratic representation and injures the interests of Arizona constituents.
Grijalva has expressed a desire to meet with Johnson to resolve the standoff and avoid further public conflict.
The case is being litigated in Washington, D.C. federal court, with the request to allow a qualified third party to administer the oath if Johnson refuses to do so.

namedEntities.name: Adelita Grijalva
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly elected Democratic member of Congress from Arizona who was refused a swearing-in by House Speaker Mike Johnson.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the central figure in the dispute over the legitimacy and timing of the swearing-in process, representing the elected member who is being delayed from taking office.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Republican Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, who refused to administer the oath of office to Adelita Grijalva.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His decision to delay the swearing-in is the focal point of the legal and political controversy, tied to constitutional interpretation and political strategy.

namedEntities.name: Kris Mayes
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Arizona’s Attorney General, who filed the lawsuit against the House of Representatives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the legal representative of the state of Arizona, asserting constitutional rights and challenging the authority of the Speaker to delay swearing-in.

namedEntities.name: Nancy Pelosi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, cited by Mike Johnson as precedent for delaying swearing-in during recesses.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her past actions are referenced by Johnson as justification for his current decision, forming a basis of political precedent under discussion in the lawsuit.

namedEntities.name: Jeffrey Epstein
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A convicted sex offender whose records are the subject of a petition in the House to release.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The lawsuit alleges that Johnson’s delay is aimed at blocking a petition related to Epstein records, suggesting political motives behind the delay.

namedEntities.name: U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The legislative body in which the conflict over seating Grijalva is taking place.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The institution is central to the constitutional and procedural dispute over the oath of office and the rights of newly elected members.

namedEntities.name: Arizona
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. state whose attorney general filed a lawsuit to protect the rights of its elected representative.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The state is asserting its interest in democratic representation and constitutional compliance, positioning itself as a key external actor in the legal dispute.

namedEntities.name: Washington, D.C. federal court
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The judicial body where the lawsuit has been filed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the venue through which the constitutional challenge to the Speaker’s authority is being adjudicated.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Arizona’s attorney general, Kris Mayes, has filed a lawsuit against the U.S. House of Representatives, alleging that Speaker Mike Johnson unlawfully delayed the swearing-in of newly elected Democrat Adelita Grijalva from Arizona, citing a constitutional obligation to seat duly elected members. Johnson claims he is following precedent established by former Speaker Nancy Pelosi, asserting he will only administer the oath upon the House’s return from recess. However, the lawsuit argues that the Constitution does not grant the Speaker authority to unilaterally delay swearing-in, especially when no constitutional or practical reason exists for refusal. The suit claims Johnson’s delay is politically motivated—aimed at blocking a petition on Jeffrey Epstein records and advancing his position in budget negotiations. Arizona argues that the delay harms democratic representation and the interests of its constituents. The case is now being heard in Washington, D.C. federal court, with a request to allow a qualified third party to administer the oath if Johnson refuses.
title: Arizona Sues Over Mike Johnson’s Refusal to Swear In Democrats’ Newest Congresswoman
